items.title: Goodbye Spotify, Hello Tidal
items.content_html: After the 14 day Tidal trial, it was time to decide to stay with Spotify or move to Tidal. I prefer the new music suggestions that Spotify presents, but much prefer the UI of Tidal. I‚Äôve also got fed up waiting for Spotify to deliver the promised HiFi streaming functionality, which is important to me as I have a Naim streamer that is capable of making good use of the hi-res delivered by Tidal. You guessed it, I‚Äôve moved to Tidal.
items.content_text: After the 14 day Tidal trial, it was time to decide to stay with Spotify or move to Tidal. I prefer the new music suggestions that Spotify presents, but much prefer the UI of Tidal. I‚Äôve also got fed up waiting for Spotify to deliver the promised HiFi streaming functionality, which is important to me as I have a Naim streamer that is capable of making good use of the hi-res delivered by Tidal. You guessed it, I‚Äôve moved to Tidal.

items.title: Spotify or Tidal?
items.content_html:
I‚Äôve flipped between both over the years, but currently using Spotify as I got a free six-month subscription when I bought a Sonos sound bar before Christmas. That‚Äôs about to expire, and it‚Äôs time to stump up ¬£9.99 a month.

The question is, should I go back to Tidal or stick where I am?

I listen to music on my MacBook, iPad, my phone and a couple of Sonos speakers located throughout the house. We also have a Naim streamer in the lounge, which means that I can make the best use of a high-quality source as provided by Tidal‚Äôs HiFi tier.

Spotify uses its Connect technology to send music to the Naim, whereas Tidal integrates with the Naim app, making for a more involved experience.

The only way to solve the puzzle is to have a sound off, play the same track on Spotify and Tidal and check whether I can hear a difference between the two to justify paying ¬£20 a month for Tidal.

I‚Äôve signed up for a 30-day Tidal trial. Let the games begin!

üéµ
items.content_text:
I‚Äôve flipped between both over the years, but currently using Spotify as I got a free six-month subscription when I bought a Sonos sound bar before Christmas. That‚Äôs about to expire, and it‚Äôs time to stump up ¬£9.99 a month.

_The question is, should I go back to Tidal or stick where I am?_

I listen to music on my MacBook, iPad, my phone and a couple of Sonos speakers located throughout the house. We also have a Naim streamer in the lounge, which means that I can make the best use of a high-quality source as provided by Tidal‚Äôs HiFi tier.

Spotify uses its Connect technology to send music to the Naim, whereas Tidal integrates with the Naim app, making for a more involved experience.

The only way to solve the puzzle is to have a sound off, play the same track on Spotify and Tidal and check whether I can hear a difference between the two to justify paying ¬£20 a month for Tidal.

I‚Äôve signed up for a 30-day Tidal trial. Let the games begin!

üéµ

items.content_html:
Goodbye Evernote, hello Craft. I’ve done what I thought was unthinkable. After using Evernote for over a dozen years, I just cancelled my subscription and started using Craft as my full time note taking application. I tried to stay loyal to Evernote, but feel they are slipping behind and I really like what the team at Craft are doing. All that’s missing are tables (on the way) and a web clipper, also on the development list.

üìù
items.content_text:
**Goodbye Evernote, hello Craft.** I've done what I thought was unthinkable. After using Evernote for over a dozen years, I just cancelled my subscription and started using [Craft](https://www.craft.do/) as my full time note taking application. I tried to stay loyal to Evernote, but feel they are slipping behind and I really like what the team at Craft are doing. All that's missing are tables (on the way) and a web clipper, also on the development list.

üìù

Lunchtime!

I took this using my Sony a6300 and 16-70mm lens at 70mm. The camera was connected to my iPad via WiFi and I used the Sony app to remotely fire the shutter. The shot was hampered by the short lens and the WiFi signal, which meant i had to position the camera further away from the feeder than was optimum.

items.title: Moved to Micro.blog
items.content_html:
I‚Äôve just completed the signup process for a Micro.blog subscription and will be moving some posts from my old WordPress site across to micro.blog over the coming days.

I‚Äôve decided to use the Arabica theme for the web and have made a couple of small changes to the Archive page, to keep links looking the same across the site ‚Äî I didn‚Äôt like the Nav bar looking and behaving different from the Categories on the Archive page. I just need to work out how to get the Categories to display horizontally now. I tried to use CSS to style them, but whilst I can change colours, etc., ‚Äúdisplay: inline‚Äù doesn‚Äôt work as you’ll see below.

Happy to take advice from anyone who has more experience using CSS than I do ‚Äî which‚Äôll be pretty much everyone.

My next challenge is to style the dates on the Archive page to look like the dates on the rest of the theme.

Still to do:

  1. Decide whether to keep my old domain name and transfer it to Micro.blog

Oh, by the way, this post was written in Ulysses and published direct to the blog.
items.content_text: I‚Äôve just completed the signup process for a Micro.blog subscription and will be moving some posts from my old WordPress site across to micro.blog over the coming days. I‚Äôve decided to use the Arabica theme for the web and have made a couple of small changes to the Archive page, to keep links looking the same across the site ‚Äî I didn‚Äôt like the Nav bar looking and behaving different from the Categories on the Archive page. I just need to work out how to get the Categories to display horizontally now. I tried to use CSS to style them, but whilst I can change colours, etc., ‚Äúdisplay: inline‚Äù doesn‚Äôt work as you'll see below. Happy to take advice from anyone who has more experience using CSS than I do ‚Äî which‚Äôll be pretty much everyone. My next challenge is to style the dates on the Archive page to look like the dates on the rest of the theme. Still to do: 1. Decide whether to keep my old domain name and transfer it to Micro.blog Oh, by the way, this post was written in Ulysses and published direct to the blog.

items.title: Working with Ulysses & Micro.blog
items.content_html:
I have recently started to use Ulysses for all my long and short-form writing and was intrigued to read that the authors added the ability to publish to micro.blog in the latest release.

I built my website on WordPress using the Extra theme and Divi builder from Elegant Themes. Whilst I‚Äôm happy with the features and functionality that Extra & Divi provides, it‚Äôs difficult to justify the annual cost of around ¬£85 a year for a hobby blog.

Ulysses posts to WordPress but the formatting doesn‚Äôt work with the Extra theme, so wasn‚Äôt really a viable option. This limitation, coupled with the cost, were the reasons behind why I was looking for an alternative blogging platform.

Setting up Ulysses to post to micro.blog was simple and took less than a minute. Exporting to micro.blog is also straightforward ‚Äî you just select ‚ÄúPublishing‚Äù as the export option and select the blog to post to, it‚Äôs status (draft, publish or schedule when it‚Äôs posted) and choose a category.
üìù
items.content_text:
I have recently started to use [Ulysses](https://ulysses.app/ "Ulysses app") for all my long and short-form writing and was intrigued to read that the authors added the ability to publish to micro.blog in the latest release. I built my [website](https://keithpound.com/ "KeithPound.com") on WordPress using the Extra theme and Divi builder from [Elegant Themes](https://www.elegantthemes.com/ "Elegant Themes site"). Whilst I‚Äôm happy with the features and functionality that Extra & Divi provides, it‚Äôs difficult to justify the annual cost of around ¬£85 a year for a hobby blog. Ulysses posts to WordPress but the formatting doesn‚Äôt work with the Extra theme, so wasn‚Äôt really a viable option. This limitation, coupled with the cost, were the reasons behind why I was looking for an alternative blogging platform. Setting up Ulysses to post to micro.blog was simple and took less than a minute. Exporting to micro.blog is also straightforward ‚Äî you just select ‚ÄúPublishing‚Äù as the export option and select the blog to post to, it‚Äôs status (draft, publish or schedule when it‚Äôs posted) and choose a category.
üìù

items.content_html:
Photos from the Rockefeller Centre, NY viewing platform.

We visited New York in March 2019 and booked a trip up the Rockefeller Centre. Unfortunately, it was very cloudy and we were presented with a whiteout, so photographing the NY skyline was out of the question and meant that I had to concentrate on the details.

üì∑

items.title: Monday Music Mix: Best of 2020
items.content_html:
It’s been a tough year for us all, but many artists released some great new music during 2020. I’ve listened to dozens of new albums, and this playlist includes some of what I thought was the best tracks.

My Album of the Year had to be Letter to You from Bruce Springsteen.

I hope you enjoy some of the tracks I’ve chosen. Leave a comment with your suggestions.

¬†See you in 2021!

üé∂

items.title: 12 Go-To Albums
items.content_html:
One of my ITfM Radio colleagues challenged his Facebook buddies to list their top 12 go-to albums recently. The aim was not to overthink the list, but to put down whatever came to mind.

That was never going to happen and it took me about a week to come up with this list.

My top 12 Go-To Albums

  1. Yes - Relayer
  2. Bruce Springsteen - The River
  3. Elbow - The Takeoff and Landing of Everything
  4. Frazey Ford - Indian Ocean
  5. Led Zeppelin - Physical Graffiti
  6. Anathema - Distant Satellites
  7. Darius Rucker - True Believers
  8. Dwight Yoakam - Blame the Vain
  9. Bob Harris Presents Vol 2
  10. Muse - Absolution
  11. Ryan Adams - Gold
  12. Genesis - The Lamb Lies Down on Broadway

I’ve included links to the album on Spotify where available so that you can listen to my top 12 go-to albums. I’m sure that you wont agree with my choices, but try to pick your top 12 …. its harder than you think it will be.

üé∂
